contentrichtext.text: {{unreferenced|date=July 2008}} '''Microwave plasma''' is a type of [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]], that has high frequency [[electromagnetic radiation]] in the [[GHz]] range. It is capable of exciting [[electrode]]less [[gas discharge]]s. ==Properties of microwave-excited plasma== If applied in [[surface-wave-sustained mode]], they are especially well suited to generate large-area plasmas of high [[plasma density]]. If they are both in [[surface-wave-sustained mode|surface-wave]] and [[resonator mode]], they can exhibit a high degree of spatial localisation. This allows to spatially separate the location of plasma generations from the location of surface processing. Such a separation (together with an appropriate gas-flow scheme) may help reduce the negative effect, that particles released from a processed substrate may have on the [[plasma chemistry]] of the [[gas phase]]. ==See also== * [[Afterglow plasma]] * [[Gas discharge]] * [[List of plasma (physics) articles]] * [[Sulfur lamp]] ==External links== * [http://jlnlabs.online.fr/plasma/gmrtst/ Generating plasmoid in household microwave oven.] * [http://www.fbh-berlin.com/business-areas/microwave-components-systems/microwave-plasma/ Atmospheric microwave microplasma sources at Ferdinand-Braun-Institut (FBH).] {{Mass spectrometry}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Microwave Plasma}} [[Category:Plasma physics]]
